translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
Fifth Section🔽The Discussion of Knowledge of the Present
“Is there knowledge of the present?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: tena ñāṇena tam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “By that knowledge does one know that knowledge?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: tena ñāṇena tam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “By that knowledge does one know that knowledge?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: tena ñāṇena tam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “By that knowledge does one know that knowledge as ‘knowledge’?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: tena ñāṇena tam ñāṇam jānāti iti
translated: “By that knowledge does one know that knowledge as ‘knowledge’?”
“Yes.”
“Is that knowledge the object of that knowledge?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is that knowledge the object of that knowledge?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Tena phassena taṁ phassaṁ phusati, tāya vedanāya taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, tāya saññāya🔽taṁ saññaṁ sañjānāti, tāya cetanāya taṁ cetanaṁ ceteti, tena cittena taṁ cittaṁ cinteti,
analyzed: āmantā  tena phassena tam phassam phusati tāya vedanāya tam vedanam vedeti tāya saññāya  tam saññam sañjānāti tāya cetanāya tam cetanam ceteti tena cittena tam cittam cinteti
translated: “Yes.”🔽“By that contact does one contact that contact, by that feeling does one feel that feeling, by that perception does one perceive that perception, by that volition does one will that volition, by that consciousness does one cognize that consciousness,

original: tena vitakkena taṁ vitakkaṁ vitakketi, tena vicārena taṁ vicāraṁ vicāreti, tāya pītiyā
analyzed: tena vitakkena tam vitakkam vitakketi tena vicārena tam vicāram vicāreti tāya pītiyā
translated: by that applied thought does one think with that applied thought, by that sustained thought does one keep thinking with that sustained thought, by that happiness does one be happy with that happiness,

original: taṁ pītiṁ piyāyati, tāya satiyā taṁ satiṁ sarati, tāya paññāya taṁ paññaṁ pajānāti,🔽tena khaggena taṁ khaggaṁ chindati, tena pharasunā taṁ pharasuṁ tacchati, tāya kudhāriyā
analyzed: tam pītim piyāyati tāya satiyā tam satim sarati tāya paññāya tam paññam pajānāti  tena khaggena tam khaggam chindati tena pharasunā tam pharasum tacchati tāya kudhāriyā
translated: He likes that joy. He remembers that mindfulness. He understands that understanding.

original: taṁ kudhāriṁ tacchati, tāya vāsiyā taṁ vāsiṁ tacchati, tāya sūciyā taṁ sūciṁ sibbeti,🔽tena aṅgulaggena taṁ aṅgulaggaṁ parāmasati, tena nāsikaggena taṁ nāsikaggaṁ parāmasati,🔽tena matthakena taṁ matthakaṁ parāmasati, tena gūthena taṁ gūthaṁ dhovati, tena muttena
analyzed: tam kudhārim tacchati tāya vāsiyā tam vāsim tacchati tāya sūciyā tam sūcim sibbeti  tena aṅgu laggena tam aṅgu laggam parāmasati tena nāsikā aggena tam nāsikā aggam parāmasati  tena matthakena tam matthakam parāmasati tena gūthena tam gūtham dhovati tena muttena
translated: He cuts that sword with that sword. He sharpens that axe with that axe. He sharpens that adze with that adze. He sharpens that knife with that knife. He sews that needle with that needle.🔽He touches that finger with that finger. He touches that nose with that nose.🔽He touches that head with that head. He washes that excrement with that excrement. He washes that urine with that urine.

original: taṁ muttaṁ dhovati, tena kheḷena taṁ kheḷaṁ dhovati, tena pubbena taṁ pubbaṁ dhovati,
analyzed: tam muttam dhovati tena kheḷena tam kheḷam dhovati tena pubbena tam pubbam dhovati
translated: He washes that spittle with that spittle. He washes that pus with that pus.

original: tena lohitena taṁ lohitaṁ dhovatīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: tena lohitena tam lohitam dhovati iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: He washes that blood with that blood?”🔽“No, friend.”
“It’s not to be said that
‘when it’s clear, there’s knowledge’?
“Yes, friend.”🔽“It’s not to be said that

original: Nanu sabbasaṅkhāre aniccato diṭṭhe tampi ñāṇaṁ aniccato diṭṭhaṁ hotīti?
analyzed: nanu sabba saṅkhāre aniccataḥ diṭṭhe tat pi ñāṇam aniccataḥ diṭṭham hoti iti
translated: “When all formations are seen as impermanent, isn’t the knowledge that sees that also seen as impermanent?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci sabbasaṅkhāre aniccato diṭṭhe tampi ñāṇaṁ aniccato diṭṭhaṁ hoti, tena vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci sabba saṅkhāre aniccataḥ diṭṭhe tam pi ñāṇam aniccataḥ diṭṭham hoti tena vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”
“When all formations are seen as impermanent, the knowledge that sees that is also seen as impermanent. So it must be said that there is knowledge of what is present.”
The Discussion of Knowledge of What is Present is finished.
